title: What will the European Central Bank (ECB) do with respect to the deposit rate at its January 2017 monetary-policy meeting?
preds: Probably maintain do to instability right now. Could go lower in the future.
All in for maintain. It is a wait and see as the Economy has not done well for that wrong. With Trump coming in may mean instability so they will wait.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Just come back to this forecast after a few weeks away from it.  We're 5 days out from the forecast.  General market consensus is Maintain.  I'm confident that Maintain is the way to go. No seriously adverse economic news in the past quarter.  ECB made a strong commitment to extend asset purchases until December 2017 during the December 2016 meeting (http://www.tradingeconomics.com/articles/12082016125409.htm).  I believe there is no need for further QE or lowering rates and all the sounds coming through the news indicates that the ECB thinks the same thing. 100% Maintain.

The recent policy announcement by the Federal Reserve to hike interest rates by 0.25% should provide the European Central Bank with some breathing space. As the interest rate spread between the the Euro Area and US increases, this should help improve the competitiveness for the Eurozone.  While inflation has been increasing over the past few months, it has yet to reach the ECB's target of 2% (current levels: 1.1%, source: http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2017/01/04/world/europe/ap-eu-europe-economy.html?_r=0), along with high levels of unemployment (9.8% as of November 2016, source: http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php/Unemployment_statistics), I believe that the ECB will not increase rates. On the other hand, we shouldn't expect to see any monetary easing given increasing political pressure imposed by Germany.  Once again, asymmetric policy reaction functions at the effective lower bound should deter the ECB from hiking rates prematurely.
Raising slightly. Reuters had Article on minutes from an ECB meeting and expectations are they will keep everything steady even though Economy stronger.

There will not be enough data given recent political developments in the U.S., as well as controversies involving the U.S., Russia and other European nations. More will need to be known before a decision is made.
It is likely to raise at some point in the future, but not on Jan 19
According to the market futures implied volatility
The ECB won't follow the Fed, at this time.

The ECB said it was keeping  its interest rates unchanged at its December meeting https://www.ecb.europa.eu/press/pressconf/2016/html/is161208.en.html. Asset purchases will change down a notch from €80 billion to €60 billion in March to April, if inflation is worrying them on the upside it would make sense to adjust this before changing interest rates. Inflation came in higher than expected but the ECB explicitly want this so would be odd to raise rates now to counter it. Leaving it at 97% now as the ECB has done odd things before in the past.
Uncertain times call for a steady hand

They will be still sceptical about the european monetary policy and also will look a the chances of inflation in the US. With a China on a possible staglaflation and the prospect of an uncertain economic future, the ECB will maintain it.
Some green shoots being seen, but lack of coordinated strategy.

Employement participation rates are far below expectations of the general population across much of Europe.
Employment satisfaction is low. 
There is common misconception that the best solution is greater investment.

The ECB will most probably maintain its current deposit rate and neither raise nor lower it. 
This is a useful chart to demonstrate the previous decisions:
http://www.tradingeconomics.com/euro-area/interest-rate
Furthermore, the ECB has just recently announced that it will extended its programme of quantitative easing until December 2017, therefore there is less of a case for them to raise the rate.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

There is inflation and they will want stability. Banks want them to raise it because it is a problem for their business model and leveraging in other areas of economy could be a problem. With Brexit looming and other problems I am going to bet they opt for stability before changes are made.

I am just a simple algorithm. On each question, Iook at those players whom I follow, and copy the forecast of one of the several who have made the most recent forecasts. I only use my own judgment when deciding which one to follow if several have made recent forecasts. So far, this works pretty well. As of 1-7-2016: Iran: 3210 Forecasters; rank: 307; 19 scored questions; Brier 0.283; Median 0.323; Accuracy -0.254 
Economist: 6485 Forecasters; rank: 97; 24 scored questions; Brier 0.202; Median 0.242; Accuracy -0.701 
Fun: 4290 Forecasters; rank 540; 8 scored questions; Brier 0.512; Median 0.49; Accuracy -0.245 
Geopolitical 2016: 7942 Forecasters; rank 32; 73 scored questions; Brier 0.206; Median 0.231; Accuracy -1.614 
Vehicles: 1530 Forecasters; rank 21; 10 scored questions; Brier 0.274; Median 0.61; accuracy -1.401

European gov't debt crisis still unsolved; Italy shows no signs of improvement; spark of Inflation basically completely due to oil price increase; unemployment not significantly decreasing throughout Europe; Draghi will take no action that might help Front National in the presidential election.
But ECB might announce to further reduce bond purchase program...
To follow economic trends of the EuroZone

Inflation had a proper increase in December. So very slight possibility of raising rates. But inflation still far off target so most probably not. Unlikely that any other factors would have an influence at this stage e.g. oil prices.

The details of the problems in the Euro area have changed a little; inflation has increased to 1.1%, Deutsche Bank looks a less weak than it did, the banking crisis in Italy remains. The world will be welcoming a new US President the day after the ECB meeting (and who knows what that will mean). It does not sound like the time to risk changing interest rates.
ECB will not further erode Banking sector profitability by further rate cats. Hikes will also be off the table due to a recently extended QE program. ECB clearly in wait and see mode.
Guessing, based on thoughtful comments of others.
Economy is restored largely, so the rate won't decrease and perhaps even raise.

The average over the past ~15 years seems to be about 2%. Unemployment is falling back to normal levels, so I doubt they will lower any further. There is some chance they could raise again but it feels premature and they haven't in the previous months. Also, I don't see any news chatter online about the possibility of it raising this month. Given the meeting is in about two weeks I'm using that lack of awareness to increase my confidence by a few % toward "maintain."

The fundamentals of a European recovery remain weak and the central bank will see no reason to raise rates. However, it would not lower the rate further as the current rates itself are perceived to be the last bullets in a failing gun.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
no upsetting of the apple-cart so early in the year
The ECB still has room to manoeuvre with QE before it chooses t tinker with deposit rates

-Eurozone economy is still in a slow recovery mode
-Italy need a weak EUR to sort out its banking sector issues
-France abd Germany will need strong economic performance before going to the polls
The have already indicated reduction in QE. Will keep rates stable until.that plays out in markets.
Increased raise chance to be more aligned with FED policy.
As implied by the futures markets. I believe financial markets are efficient (Efficient Market Hypothesis).
Inflation in the EU will still low while unemployment will be in the 2 digits. Also, the real effect of President Trump in the EU will still be uncertain.
Will not want to introduce more instability until Brexit dust settles
Rare to shift guidance so quickly and no pressing reason to do so.
ECB usually follows US Reserve footprint. It is very unlikely to make independent decisions.

While I believe there are reasons to follow the Fed in raising rates (to maintain fx rates with the USD stable and resist a raising dollar, which with rising oil prices could have a heavy burden on a still fragile economy, to more objectively measure qe effects from buying bonds; to counter German fear of inflation raising its head), I do not believe to be smarter than the crowd, so I align to a more likely maintain than raise forecast, staying somewhat above average.
The ain't moving until the Fed pushes the dollar with the rate policy and borrowing strategies below parity to the euro.

We can rule out a Raise in rates because we know that ECB works on neo-Keynesian economic theory (generally) which says that as unemployment is still above natural rate and there is little inflation we should lower rates.  At the very least, DON'T raise rates!  This is supported by their announcement to leave rates at "present or lower levels for an extended period of time, and well past the horizon of net asset purchases" (NAP runs till at least December 2017). I'm leaning towards Maintain because I've been relatively convinced by the argument that the ECB is interested in using other strategies rather than cutting rates to achieve the stimulus it wants to achieve.  Negative deposit rates have started to create phenomena we haven't seen before (see Economist article) and many believe the ECB is slightly worried about the effects the negative interest rates are having (e.g. costs of deposit rate passed onto consumers).  I think that Draghi still sees conventional interest rate manipulation as a valid strategy but not right now. Inside View - I'm not sure I have time to do this, but someone ought to do some sort of analysis into the language Draghi uses at his press conferences and whether we can intimate any details of future announcements from previous ones.  Did his language at the December announcement belie any information for the January conference?   The text on the web that I quoted above is non-committal either way. I'll stick right in the middle between 50-50 and 100-0 at 75-25 until further notice.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Over last five years, the ECB has changed rate 5 times in 52 meetings. Therefore, my starting point is a 90% chance of maintain. ECB says maintain or lower, so would only expect major unforeseen event to lead to raise (1%). Residual 9% to lower.

First off, the ECB will not raise rates. No fundamental economic signs point to overheating or rising inflation.
Lowering is a possibility but I gave it only 13% because I figure we start with a 1 in 10 chance simply because the bank is already in uncharted territory and I know the only thing central bankers hate more than being in uncharted territory is going deeper. However, I do up the percentage a little because Mario Draghi seems like the sort of person to try everything and see what works. The ECB may feel desperate enough to try a further rate decrease.
Clearly though I think it is overwhelmingly likely that the ECB will maintain rates and identify other unconventional tools to use at their January meeting.
Don't know enough to make a reasonable prediction.
Till something new happens in Europe and the EMU
ECB will first look at effect US interest rate change, world economy and for now maintain status quo
Stability is crucial in the current climate - at least people will know where they stand.

just announced extension of QE through 2017 with dovish bias so no probably of raising while still in balance sheet expansion mode. Lower rates has the potential to hurt bank stocks which leads credit creation in the Eurozone.
Political instability, a rise might mean more bankrupt, and a fall might mean more escape.

Not the moment to raise rates yet
Lot of uncertainty in the economy

Europe is desperately trying to steady the ship amidst choppy waters. Brexit is only half the problem. Turmoil in Italian politics, the rise of the Right, and potential break-up of the Union all weigh heavily. I think they will try to sugar coat it, but will be forced to make another small reduction in the rate - perhaps to -0.50%.
ecb is locked in to keeping interest rates low.
Moving a single point from lower to raise, to cover raise better. Although maintain still my favorite.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
With the Greece crisis looming and continued uncertainty regarding growth rates the ECB will keep the rate on hold for the next few months
following the raise by the FED, ECB is more likely to follow
Strengthening maintain, on dollar interest raise.
They have just extended maturities of QE in Dec, and lowered monthly quantum. They will wait for the impact to be seen in data, which will not be enough to act in Jan.
ECB wants Euro lower versus USD, but can't below 0.
Taking out some downside bias. ECB is a bit more balanced.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

In the current situation, after the December 2016 meeting when the ECB extended their Quantitative Easing program without changing the deposit rate, I think the most likely action they will take in the January is to keep the rate steady.
The political uncertainty surrounding the EU would necessitate keeping rates stable or decreasing.
Rate moves are out, QE is in.

With dec. extension . . seems unlikely to make any changes to the deposit rate (they would have done it then). Monetary Policy decisions rarely move in consecutive meetings unless planned previously, and with this one being so close it seems highly unlikely to change.

ECB decision to continue 80b euro bond purchases per month through March 2017, then reduce to 60b euros per month through the end of 2017, seems to indicate a slight tightening of policy over time.  A further reduction of the deposit rate would move in the opposite direction.  Unless a new crisis develops, maintaining the current deposit rate seems the most consistent policy.
Money needs to circulate in order to prevent the harmful 'parking' in low risk, low return positions.
An unexpected shock may cause the ECB to lower.
Lowering is seeming very unlikely given strength of dollar, probable interest rate increase in U.S.
After today's decision, Jan 2017 looks too soon for any changes.
A lowering of the interest rate is very unlikely, since it would hit banks profits. An increase is very unlikely as well, given the unstable situation in the whole Europe.
It will keep this rate, but may change it if Italy weakens more.
Negative interest rates are not spurring spending but ECB policymakers are strongly divided.

The ECB will hold at the next meeting so as to keep some powder dry in case of further Italian difficulties.  The very small chance of a rise is due to the continuing presence of buba ultras at the ECB.
BCE is more concerned about liquidity than inflation
Caution most likely, but hike in US or Italian worries could make it go either way
there isn't a huge amount that will change by then. the market around italian banks could deteriorate. even if things deteriorate they have other options than the deposit rate.
Because their members are very conservatives

There isn't much chaos this year I Europe, Greece is out of recession, Italian banks are going to be re capitalised!. ECB can't raise or lower rates. There could also be a 50% chance for lower if the US rates rise causes capital flights out of Europe

There are no signs of recovery in the Eurozone as a whole, especially the south still has a lot of debt problems. Trumps investment plans wont change that in the short run: draghi doesn't mind if the euro slips a bit extra.

I don't really have strong intuitions about macroeconomic phenomena at all but I can say this much: http://www.reuters.com/article/us-moneymarket-ecb-rates-idUSKBN13521X "The last cut, to minus 0.40 percent, was in March this year. ECB head Mario Draghi signaled that would be the end of the road and most economists expect the central bank to keep rates at these levels for many years to support the bloc's recovery."

What appears to be a probable rise in US rates could pull other rates around the world further up, though that might have a positive effect for the ECB as it would weaken EUR (thus maintaining). It is always possible for ECB to further lower rates, but inflation and GDP data does not look drastic enough for them to do so. Uncertainty regarding the EU could lead to cuts but at the moment I can't think of any scenarios that might play out over the next 6 weeks that would lead to a cut.
Draghi´s risk aversion and immobility of UE

The increase in uncertrainty since yesterday's election in Italy call for lower interest rates overall. However, since lower deposit rates so far have not had the intended consequences of pushing more money out to the non-financial sector but caused banks to have higher costs, the ECB will probably maintain current rates.
The Europe economies are not strong. Keeping currencies weak will help with exports.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Lowering rates further will have unintentional consequences on the economy. Will revise this forecast after this week's ECB announcement.
December can be a volatile month and January don't seem a good timing for this kind of decision. Banks situation in Europe have to be considered too.
To gain strength in the GBP
The economy might be good enough, i.e. oil prices go up just a bit, to justify a rate increase back to 0.0%.

* EZ risks are too high for a hike
* ECB likely to maintain current level of interest rate for the whole of 2017
Raising will be a premature signal to tighten policy. Lowering does not fit rising inflation. Stays maintain as the base case.
I am not even gonna argue about this. You cannot possibly think otherwise.
There has not been enough of an improvement in the European economies to lead to a rise, so more likely it will be left untouched.
The CPI is up gradually and the government bond yield in EU is up. ECB has more room to buy them and keep the interest rate in the low level.
Not many reasons for a raise. It could be lowered further in case the Italian public finances and economy descend into chaos after the 4 December referendum and a Renzi resignation.
The rate has never been so low and recently there were warnings about systemic risks induced by this low.

Many economies across the globe have failed to keep up with the growth goals. Despite generally steady, but slow progress since the Great Recession, companies and banks have really not been great risk takers.(There is a qualitative difference between intentional risk taking and gambling.) Lowering the nominal rate further increases the incentive for banks/companies to invest for ROI rather than simply sitting on sidelines with a bond return.  In a tangent to US discussions of tax policy, the fundamental issue should not be, in isolation,  whether tax rates on corporations should be less or not, but rather HOW to design a tax structure that incentivizes investment. On the counter side, of course, is the impact on older savers. But, negative rates is not a long time solution and should be meant as a way to kickstart company investments. A growing economy will naturally cause rates to rise.

It does not seem that they will follow the FED with the increase, the situation there other than what it seems temporary improvement in Spain, Portugal, the rest of EU seems stagnant at best. I do not see a decline in rates, but a continuation with their bond purchases and steady rates.

So hard to say... I do not see them lowering it after having just build it up slowly. It would give an erratic feel. To be avoided I guess.  It seems to be becoming a troubled meeting with Italy... so in times of stress better to remain calm and do nothing :)
The EU is about to enter into some unchartered times. Italy's solvency and elections in France and Germany may well end the EU as we know it today.
Depending on the outcome of the Italian election and the market reaction, I assign some chance to lowering rates

- deflationary economic forces across Europe will continue to require further rate cuts until they approach zero. 
- therefore, it is most likely that rates will either be maintained or cut. Raising rates is very unlikely.

It is unlikely that they will make any changes to the policy rate until economic growth is in a safe territory. There are still several emerging political risks that are not yet fully apparent that will need to be waited out, such as an incoming trump presidency. 
I think a rate decrease is equally unlikely giving that we still have very little theoretical understanding of what nominal negative rates do, and pushing further into this territory opens up new kinds of risks that are still poorly understood.

Draghi is well aware of the risk of negative rate on banks. If the earnings of the financial system continue to the pressure, there will be long term consequences. Thus the ECB is very unlikely to lower rate further, given its limited impact this year.

I think this is key  in this story: 
http://www.wsj.com/articles/draghi-ecb-stimulus-key-ingredient-of-recovery-1480344351
"Still, he stressed that the ECB’s stimulus policies have been a key ingredient in the region’s economic recovery, and indicated they were likely to continue." Reducing 'Lower' and 'Raise' and increasing  'Maintain'

the ECB decided that the interest rate on the main refinancing operations and the interest rates on the marginal lending facility and the deposit facility will remain unchanged at 0.00%, 0.25% and -0.40% respectively. 
_____________________
COMMENT:  Interest rates have gone down since 2012 steadily; The ECB will raise them when the economy will be recovering. The question here should be will the EU economy show substantial signs of recovery by January 2017?
Not by January with all the uncertainties of Brexit, Trump, Italian referendum, France elections.
The ECB would like to keep a low rate but it will, no linger, be able to maintain it. The tide is turning.
Flip Maintain and Lower. With more uncertainty about U.S. actions on interest rates, preserving the status quo or wait and see seems the more likely action.
The world will be very unstable
It is likely that they will try to be conservative
Allowing scpoe for lower rate depending on developments in Italy and France
Unclear waters. EU economy is on the brink of a return to the good times, but probably to soon for a raise.
Ecb wants member countries to stay
Nothing will have changed from today data wise. No change expected in the deposit rate.
Dysfunctional EU institutions are last to react.ECB will not move before Fed and BoE have set worldwide direction.
Trends suggest that lowering interest rate is the path ECB choose regarding stimulating Europe economy.
In line with the wisdom of the crowds.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
They will certainly not raise rates and will probably maintain through January.
The ECB will keep rates as is as the indicators will not have changed materially

1) Weaknesses are beginning to show in the European economy especially in France where unemployment rate has recently climbed above 10%.  2) There are still too much uncertainty in the overall global market to warrant a rate increase.
January is too soon to really understand what the US president will do and to assess how or if it will damage the UK economy
Fragile economic growth allows no rate rise. Lowering of rate is no option either given that commercial banks and insurance funds are already suffering.

This statement from the ECB suggests rates will stay as they are or reduce further:
"The Governing Council continues to expect the key ECB interest rates to remain at present or lower levels for an extended period of time, and well past the horizon of the net asset purchases."
The prevailing view is that there is a small chance the deposit rate may rise towards the end of 2017. A rise before then is judged as unlikely.
http://m.investing.com/news/economy-news/slim-chance-of-an-ecb-rate-hike-next-year,-markets-show-439620

The ECB deposit rate is currently negative. This gives a lot of grief to banks, pension fund, and insurance companies, but they would keep it that way until inflation is firmly on its way toward 2 percent (not yet the case according to Draghi). On the other hand, the depreciating euro provides further relaxation, so there is no case for lowering it further.

There's a lot of instability, at the moment, so maintaining seems the most likely course. There are a few reasons to be bullish, so raising might be possible. There's little reason to lower the rates, especially given how low they already are.
I don't know anything about it
Political plus other circumstances such as result of us election,  up coming elections in European countries esp France, migrants,  rise of right wing etc won't make much change possible here
They won't change it for fear of disturbing things

With the present US bond market movements, the ECB just needs to seat on its past decision and let the dollar continue its climb, that will give the ECB enough time to see if the situation in Italy and Belgium calms down, and some numbers from exports improve and employment starts to tick up.

The ECB has more bonds available to purchase after the European rise in rates. It is more likely to increase the single issuer purchase percentage OR seek to move away from the capital key OR remove the deposit rate constraint.

Raising rates will cause chaos in the bond market. However, "the bond market may already be in chaos" by the time of the meeting. If the long end of US Treasuries yields are spiking higher and the US FED raises rates, it could spur the ECB to act and raise.
However, if the ECB raises rates it will be a token raise, perhaps by 10 or 15 basis points. I predict that rates will remain negative and place only a 1% chance that rates will become positive in January.
The bank is stuck in a deadlock where each decision either to rise or lower will have bad consequences. Maintaining also has its drawbacks but it's easier not to do anything than to take action
Lowering will increase the gap between the US which will likely have raised by then, so probably maintain with a bias toward raise.

http://www.cityam.com/254089/ecb-president-mario-draghi-maintains-central-banks-stance
In a statement to the European Parliament, he said: “We remain committed to preserving the very substantial degree of monetary accommodation necessary to secure a sustained convergence of inflation towards levels below, but close to, 2% over the medium term.”
- Strong statement indicating *not lowering*
- Also not saying *will do more / raise, etc.*
That said, ECB is not obligated to be transperent
They will be waiting for those that happen to the world-wide level and much influenced by the decisions that are taken in the USA and can affect the economy.
Some countries are starting to recover but they will not make the same mistake again and raise interest rates so quickly.
Governments in EU will not be able to reduce deficits.

All of the analysts surveyed by FocusEconomics expect the ECB to keep the policy rate unchanged at the current record-low of 0.00% this year and next.
https://www.focus-economics.com/country-indicator/eurozone/interest-rate

"The Governing Council continues to expect the key ECB interest rates to remain at present or lower levels for an extended period of time, and well past the horizon of the net asset purchases." https://www.ecb.europa.eu/press/pr/date/2016/html/pr161020.en.html
To test and better my ability to discern who and under what circumstances logic, emotion and self serving delusion are used by various actors to decide.
As someone with zero knowledge of economics, I am mystified that by the fact that the idea of making a middleman more expensive is viewed as a recipe for economic recovery.  Could someone explain?

Most likely they'll wait for the US Fed before deciding on their own move. If the Fed raises its rate, that would be effectively be a decrease for the ECB by default. Waiting for the Trump administration may also be prudent. Although the Euro has been falling against the dollar, it seems too early for the ECB to raise, with growth and inflation remaining below well target, and considerable political uncertainty with several elections coming up.

Against raise: Growth in the eurozone is still sluggish (.3 percent growth in 2016 Q2). Much uncertainty in the world, French elections in April (even though monetary policy's lag is usually about a year, so may not have an effect). Does not want to get bit, again, by raising rates too soon.
Against lower: already negative. ECB is fairly hawkish toward inflation and inflation did increase by its largest rate in two years (WSJ). Potentially higher rates in the US and an already rising dollar could weaken the euro and increase exports' competitiveness. 
But political disenchantment from sluggishness in the eurozone keeps the ECB against raising rates. Hawks at the ECB and that inflation has picked up a bit push against lowering. Maintain seems most likely.

1)   Recovery of the euro area economy appears to be on track for now.
2)   The Governing Council could be able to have a firmer view on the inflation outlook going along with the good/favorable financing conditions at present.
For instance: http://www.reuters.com/article/us-moneymarket-ecb-rates-idUSKBN13521X I think they'll be on hold until they have more of an idea of Donald Trump's influence on US policy.

The bottom has been reached at -40bp, with problems arising from bank profitability with margins already razor thin, as well as the ECB cannibalizing its own own asset purchase programme by reducing the amount of eligible bonds to buy due to their low yields. Euro area Inflation is slowly picking up with six straight months of rising prices, but the ECB would be foolish to risk the recovery by raising rates too soon. Draghi has publicly criticized his predecessor Trichet when he did that in 2011. The first step will be the tapering of the APPs and only then will the ECB touch rates.
With so much uncertainty on the euro political landscape, an effort will be made to maintain the current status quo.

Two meetings are upcoming: 8 Dec. and 19 Jan. 2017.  With interest rates below the long term goal (1.8%), and the last seven rate moves have been down (since July 2011, approx. one every nine months).  Changes since 2011 have occurred in the June/July, September and December months.  A rate reduction may be more likely in December than in January. Given published statements ("expects to remain at present or lower rates for an extended period of time"), beyond the net asset purchase horizon, which is currently set at 80b Euros until, at least, March 2017, and objectives (long term inflation expectation set for 1.8%, while current inflation is around 0.2%, odds of a raise in the rate seems low. The deposit facility rate has fallen since July 2011 (0.75%), 
Sept. 2011 (0.5%), 
Dec. 2011 (0.25%), 
July 2012 (0%), 
June 2014 (-0.1%), 
Sept. 2014 (-0.2%), 
Dec. 2015 (-0.3%), 
Mar. 2016 (-0.4%).
https://www.ecb.europa.eu/press/pr/date/2016/html/pr161021.en.html

* Draghi said negative rates are generally positive but too high negative rates are probably note (http://www.wsj.com/articles/ecb-leaves-refi-deposit-rates-unchanged-1461240028) - This seems to indicate more likelihood of maintaining (or decreasing)
* Banks clearly don't like this - as it can't be passed on to consumers. ECB seems to be fairly independent though.
* There isn't much good data to indicate they'll raise it - so I think that likelihood is low.
* Very spare, but negative rate history indicates they have waited about a year between raises of two consecutive raises (http://www.wsj.com/articles/ecb-leaves-refi-deposit-rates-unchanged-1461240028). This increases 'Maintain' likelhood.
